div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1906.

div.head: THE GROWTH OF THE ENGLISH PEOPLE.
div.p: The year 1877 is one of the most memorable in the history of Bagland. It did not witness any Constitutional crisis. There was no General Election, no change of Government, no shifting of the centre of political power. The domestic legislation of the year was singularity uneventful. The country had only a second's interest in European wars. The course of commerce and industry was equally free from critical events ; it was not a time of great industrial disputes or of great mechanical inventions. The world was not smitten by pestil. ence or famine. No great man was cut off by death in the fullness of his power; if any leader of revolutions was born at that season he bas Bow reached his thirtieth year without sign. Yet a single fact, hardly noticed at the time, barely understood even now, make, the year 1877 pauk. as one of the turning points of national history, as the dramatic close of a rëvolutionary era.

Between 1876 and 1877 the number of births per thousand of the total population of England and Wales fell from 363 to 36. Por every ten tho sand of the population tb.ee fawer children were born in 1877 than in 1876. The birth rate had often varied more than this, upwards or downwards, in previous years and has varied as much again and again ip anoceeding years. The fact recorded might well seem utterly trivial and accidental. Subsequent history has proved it to be neither. The last annual report of the Registrar-General, which was issued a week or two ago, shows that the alight fall in the birth rate between 1876 and 1877 was only the first stage in a progressive decrease which has continued with but occasional intermission ever since and which has brought the number of births per thousand persons living down to 27:9 in 1904, the lowest recorded since the beginning of registra|tion. Up to 1876 the birth rate, though subject to continual variations, rose on the whole steadily throughout the period for which stati{tics are available; from an average of 32 per thousand in the years 1841-45 it reached an average of 35-5 per thousand in the years 1871-75. It attained its highest point in 1876, and then fell with catastrophic swiftness. In less than ten years the increase of the previous. thirty-five years disappeared ; in leşs than thirty the birth rate has come from 86-8 in 1876 to 27 9 in 1904—a fall of 23 per cent. Pew things in the vital history of the nation are so dramatic as this slow rise and - rapid decline of its fertility. Hardly any involves more important consequences or gives rise to more serious speculations.

It is indeed easy, to overestimate, or rather to mistake, the effects of even so great a decrease as one quarter in the fertility of the nation. First, the falling English birth rate is no isolated phenomenon ; it is only a single instance of a general tendepoy affecting substantially the-whole of Western Barope. In Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Germany, Prance, Holland, Belgium, Italy, and Hungary the birth rate has fallen markedly during the past quarter of a century. In Austin, Switzerland, Russia, and Spaid it is stationary. In Roumania and Bulgaria it has risen. In our Australasian Colonies the fall has been even more marked than in the United Kingdom itself. Second, the effects of a falling birth rate have been partially counteracted by a fall in the death rate. In 1876 the death rate for England and Wales was 209 per thousand persons living ; the difference between that and the birth rate of 36.3, commonly described as the "natural increase" of the population, was 15.4. In 1904 the birth rate I had fallen to 27.9, the death rate to 16.2, and the "natural increase" to 11.7. Yet this way of calculating the change, though it makes the actual drop in the rate of natural increase, leaves it relatively to the earlier period I quite as great. The rate of natural increase of the population: by excess of births over deaths is just three quarters of what it was | less than thirty years ago. That is the net result of our falling birth rate and of our enormously improved sanitary and medical provision for keeping men alive.

The figures as given are vitiated by certain technical defects. Yet not the most scientific of statisticians would deny the substantial validity of the inference based on them. In a scientific paper read to the British Association in 1894, Mr. Edward Cannan argued that the population of England and Wales might be expected to become stationary during the last decade of the Twentieth Century. The figures again must be left to speak for themselves. No explanation can be offered here of the tremendous though silent change of physical habits which has affected the whole Western world during the last quarter of a century, whose beginning can be placed so definitely for England in the years 1876-77. One thing at least seemscertain : 80, complete and sudden a reversal of the earlier tendanoy must have been due to very deep-seated opules, and is therefore hardly to be counteracted by ordinary humanarta-by legislation or writing or preaching. It is not clear whether the defense in the rate of national growth is a thing to be blessed or one to be banned ; it is fairly clear that it matters but little whether we bless or ban.

Por centuries preceding the Industrial Revolution at the end of the Eighteenth Century the population of Bogland and Wales remained almost stationary or grew at a rate utterly insignificant to modern eyes. In the fifty years between 1750 and 1800, when the country first began to feel the effects of the Industrial Revolution, the population increased by one-third. In the next fifty years it doubled, and in the 6fty-five years since 1850 it has almost, though not quite, doubled again. That is the outstanding feature in the material history of the Nineteenth century. A tremendous outburst of racial vigour, accompanying and stimulated by the development of mechanical arts has in less than a hundred and fifty years replaced a Battered agricultural community of seven millions by the crowded industrial community of thirty-four millions which fills Bogland and Wales to-day. During all this period tremendous growth of population and of all activities dependent upon population-banofactores, export and import trade, cities,national income. -has been taken as part of the natural order. When Mill in 1865 wrote his famous chapter on the "stationary state" in which population should have ceased to grow he wrote as one imagining a fanciful paradox. Now the stationary state—though its actoa) advent may be continually postponed by improvements in the art of saving life is almost within sight; at least, forces which may bring it about are working visibly in our midst. After a contrary of ever swifter growth the forces of increase seem to have spent themselves ; in 1877 the material history of the race turned a corner suddenly. The growth of the modern nation may be destined to end with the Twentieth Century as definitely as it began at the end of the Eighteenth.

The effects of such a change both upon social life and apon political speculation would be enormous. There appears to be no good reason for looking forward to them as disastrous. The cessation of numerical growth in Great Britain would not moan the cessation of pomerical growth in the British Empire ; still lose would it involve the creation of all growth of prosperity, of all development in human nature. The continual pressure of the rising generation upon all the avenges of employment, which now drives out many an older man before his time, would cease. The nation would have sase from the pains of growing in bulk, and might tbus secure the more universal distribution or prosperity and growth in other directions. In the history of the race the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries would appear simply as a time of tran-formation; the creation of violent growth would leave the tranefortnéd people free to use its developed powers. (The "Morning Post").

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 4.45 p.m. to-day.

div.head: Buried Alive.
div.p: A native workman was engaged in digging a pit at Mex yesterday when a landslip occurred and he was buried alive. When he was extracted from the débris life was found to be extinct.

div.head: A. S. C.
div.p: Lotteries in connection with tomorrow's racing on the A. S. C. grounds will be held at the Cercle Khedivial this evening at 9 o'clock. Lotteries will also take place on Friday at the same hour. Mouled ef Nebi.

The feast of the Prophet will be celebrated on the 6th inst, at Abbassieh, where H. H. the Khedive will preside over the ceremony. On Såtarday evening Sheikh Tewfik el-Bakri will read the Prophet's life in Arabic and on Sunday morning the same will be read in the Tarkish language.

div.head: Fires at Alexandria.
div.p: During last year 87 outbreaks of fire were notified to the Alexandria Fire Brigade, as against 58 in the preceding year. Of this number, 53 were put out by the brigade. Only 10 were serious, i.o., where the losses exceeded one-sixth of the value of the property. Of the 87 fires, 25 buildings were insured. The value of the property destroyed by firo amounted to LE. 31743, as against LR, 49,756 in 1904.

div.head: Popular University.
div.p: The following is the course of the free lectures for May at the Popular University, which all are invited to attend :- Sat. 5, "Science et Civilisation" ( in French ) by Dr. Axisa ; Sat. 12, "Le transformisme et la littérature" (in French) by Mr. Lonia Fleri ; Sat. 19, "Evolution, éducation et religion" (in Italian) by Dr. Calzolari ; Sat. 26; "LA latte pour la vie et sa portée sociale" (in French) by Mr. Raoul G. Capivet.

div.head: The Summer Season,
div.p: The arrival of his Highness the Khedive marks the official commencement of the summer season, so propitious to leisure. The abatement of business will permit many to realize their long-folt desires to avail themselves at the Berlitz Schools (1, Sharia Kamel, Cairo, and 12, rue Rosette, Alexandria) of the courses of Baglish, French, Arabio, oto, by. the celebrated method which has evoked universal admiration. (Advt.)

div.head: Railway Carriage on Fire.
div.p: Travellers to and from Ramleh yesterday evening after 8 o'clock witnessed the un. osoal spectacle of a railway carriage entirely enveloped in flames. Owing to some unknown cause fire broke out in a service car which was being rent to Cairo just outside Sidi Gaber station, and in a very short space of time the car was reduced to cinders. The car was one of those used for the conveyance of high railway officials and are sumptuously fitted op. It weg valued at £500.

div.head: Weevil-Rexisting Cotton,
div.p: The "Board of Trade Journal" states that the British Chargé d'Affaires at Guatemala has forwarded a sample of cotton grown in the Retalhuleu district of Western Guatemala, known as Pachon and said to be possessed of special weevil-resisting characteristics. It is a short season cotton, productive, and ripening very early, with a fibre of good length and texture. The rapid ripening tends, to leave the weevil without opportunity to breed doring a large portion of the year. Experiments have already been made at Lapham (Maryland), and further experiments are pending.

div.head: An Apology
div.p: In our issue of February 6, 1906, we published a reprint of an article written by the Rev. Howard Johnson, D.D., which appeared originally in "The Herald and Presbyter.". In the said article certain allegations were made against the chaplain at Luxor, whose conduct a clergy can was held up to opprobrium by the writer. It has since some to our knowledge that these allegations were entirely untrue.

We regret to learn that the publication of the said article should have caused pain and annoyance to the Rev. A. W. Gross, who was chaplain at Luxor during the past season, and we willingly tønder this gentleman our sincere apologies.

div.head: CAIRO'S ICE SUPPLY.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes :

It is most sincerely to be hoped that the Government will take notice of the justice of the complaints of "Norquam con paratas," which appeared in- Friday'' issue of your widely circulated paper. It is scandalous that å great city of nearly a million inhabitants should be dependent on a single company for its ice sapply. In a climate such as this ice is one of the first necessaries of life and it is im. possible to understand why the Government allowed it to be a monopoly. The failure in the ice supply here during the sweltering days of last week was a public scandal of the first mag. nitude and immediato stops ought to be taken by the Government to awaken the company to some sense of the duties which it owes to the public.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: THE BUDGET. CONSERVATIVE ESTIMATES EXCEEDED
div.p: The "Time," says that the Chancellor of the Exchequer's Budget speech was of an eminently business-like character, though possessing few of the ornaments with which his predecessors have generally striven to enliven their figures. The conservative estimates formed by Mr. Austen Chamberlain have been exceeded, making the work of Mr. Asquith comparatively light. The Press generally expresses this view. Though the absence of any reduction in the income tax is disappointing. satisfaction is expressed with the promised Select Committee to enquire into the position.

div.head: NIGHT DISINFECTION OF SHIPS.
div.p: The Quarantine Board has decided that the disinfection of vessels in quarantine may be affected during the night, provided that the lighting by electricity is considered as amply Sufficient by the quarantine officials.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN CYPRUS.
div.p: Medical inspection is now imposed on arrivals from Egypt in Cyprus With the disinfection of merchandise and the effects of deck passengers from Egypt. These measures must be undergone at Larnaca or Limassol.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: A case of plague was discovered in Cairo on Monday. The victim was a native, who was found dead at Rod-el-Perag, and who had come from Deshna. Seven fresh cases (three of which were fatal) and three deaths in hospital were recorded at Deshna on Monday, and one fresh case, one death, and threé recoveries in Samalout district.

div.head: THE KHEDIVAH.
div.p: H.H. the Khedivah, on arriving at Bidi Gaber station on Monday, was received by the girls of the Orwa el Woska Society's Bobool. One of the pupils' delivered a speech of welcome to her Highness, who appeared pleased with this attention, and presented the mistress of the girls with a brooch set with diamonds and gave £6 to be distributed among the girls.

div.head: THE ARMENIAN COMMUNITY.
div.p: The Armenians were constituted into a recognised community by the Sultan of Turkey about fifty years ago. It is stated that according to this constitution, the members are empowered to elect the committee of their community and the president is elected by the committee. It is stated that Bartaa Pacha was not elected by the committee, but by the Patriarch of the Armenians, Monsignor Ormanian, at Constantinople. Bartan Pasha is said to have acted in too authoritative a manner as president and has filled up the committee with his own nominees.

The tablet erected in the Armenian charoh by Bartau. Pacha was purposely broken on Sunday last as a sign of the popular displeasure. The Pachs on this tablet declared that he had spent L E. 350 on repairs to the church. The fact that the amount of money spent by the Pacha was engraved on the tablet caused displeasure because it was not considered good taste, especially as the builder of the church, Youssefian Bey, a relation of Nabar Pacha, never made such a display of his generosity to the community.

Another cause of complaint is that the president of the community should be a local sobject, for in accordance with the constitution it is not in order, so we are informed, to nomi| nate the subject of a foreign Power to such a position, and Bartau Pasha is a Russian subject.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Satisfied yesterday afternoon from Liverpool, and is due here about 14th in with passengers,' mails, and general cargo.
The Canard SS. Paxia Balled yesterday afternoon for Liverpool with a fall cargo, including 1,179 bales of cotton and 25,281 bags of onions.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE. STATEMENT IN THE LORDS.EGYPTIAN TERRITORY DEFINED.
div.p: Lord Fitzmaurice, replying to Lord Monkswell | in the House of Lords, said that El Rafah and El Areesh formed part of Egypt proper, while the Sinai peninsula, though it did not form part of Egypt proper, to (sic) remain ander audispated Egyptian administration.

div.head: THE GHAZI INTERVIEWED.
div.p: H. E. Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha has been interviewed by Mastaph: Paoba Kamel, and the following account of his Excellency's assertions is given in "Al Lewa" :

On this question of the frontier dispute I am only giving - vent to the wishes of my Imperial Master, the Sultan, and of his Govern. ment. The Sublime Porte only wants what is just, so I do not think that any further difficulties will occur over the present matter. The Ottoman Government does not intend to make good its claims by foros, although three Tarkish army corps numbering not less than 800,000 men, are now encamped near the boundaries of Egypt. All those who are making mountains out of molehills over this question are only working agar at the interests of Turkey. Egypt, and England, and against the peace of the world in general. Should the present state of affairs necessitate a conference for the discussion of the difference, Turkey would, I suppose, agree to sūch a step with pleasure for her objects are quite pacific. If the Egyptians will accept my advice I should warn them to pay not the slightest heed to the insults which some people are now horling against their Sultan and his role in order to excite their minds. Egypt's welfare demands perfect peace between the different sects and races living here. The Ottomans appreciate the love and affection, which the Egyptians bear towards their Suzerain Power and their illustrious Saltın, and their loyalty should be 'founded on a desire for peace and for the prosperity of Egypt.

As far as we can gather, all the news from the frontier confirms the statements of the "Mokattam's" correspondent that Egyptian telegraph poles have been appropriated and the boundary pillars demolished, and that a small Tarkish force is stationed over a mile to the west of the boundary,

div.head: A SERIOUS SYMPTOM
div.p: We believe that on or about the 7th or 8th of last month four siege güns were landed at Beyront and dispatched with the utmost secrecy to Damascus.

div.head: BARON OPPENHEIM'S MISSION.
div.p: The Gazette" denies the rumour that Baron von Oppenheim has gone to Syria in order to stir up the Turks against England.
(Havas)
The Cairo Press still occupies itself with the mystery surrounding some recent movements of Baron Max von Oppenheim, of the German Agency. The "Pyramides" remarks:

Il est entendu, c'est le Progrès qui l'affirme, que le baron Max von Oppenheim n'a jamais eu l'intention d'aller en Syrie et qu'il n'a jamais quitté le Caire ces temps ci- son voyage à Port-Said était sans doute hallucination pare! 1- mais nous nous permettrons de poser an

Progrès, une simple question : Pourquoi dono avant de partir en congé, le distingué conseillent la légation d'Allemagne donne-t-il de si: fréquents dîners à certaines hautes notabilités syriennes, où l'on parle entre la poire et le fromage de toute autre chère que d'archéologie?' |

It is stated that the German mission, whose journey was stopped by the Governor of El Areesh, had been originally prohibited from pursuing its march by the Turkish commandant at Rafah, but when the leader of the mission showed a certain document to the commandant it acted as an "Open Sesame" and that officer at once put men at the service of the mission and ceased all opposition to its movements.

div.head: ACCOMMODATION FOR TROOPS
div.p: The Police School was removed on Monday from the Citadel to a building situated at: Ciccolani Garden, Shonbra. The old school will be occupied by the additional troops for the Army of Occupation.

div.head: THE NEW BATTALION.
div.p: The 1st Lancashire Fusiliers are expected at Alexandria from Malta at about 12 noon to-morrow
They will entrain at Gabbari quay as early as possible after disembarkation for conveyance to Mouasla station, near the Citadel, Cairo.

div.head: ENGINE BLOWN UP BY DYNAMITE
div.p: A bad accident happened near Assonan on Friday. As the train was coming from Shellal, & camel that was carrying some cases of dynamite took fright at the approaching train, and dropped a case on the line, near the junction. The train coming upon it exploded, hurling the engine several yards away, killing the driver and fireman, and injuring three more persons, one dangerously. Exact details are not to hand, but Mr. Mandalay, the manager of the Luxor Assuan line, has left, accompanied by the railway doctor, and a portion of the engineering staff. It is said that the camel and driver have got off, and are not to be found.

The plague now raging at Deshna and environs is not what is known as bubonic plague, but & more virulent kind called pneumonic plague. The chances of recovery are very méagre, when once the disease has got hold of a patient. The authorities are taking every precaution. Dr. Williams, who is in charge, is antiring in his efforts to stamp it out, and it is to be hoped that he will succeed.

A new mosque has been inaugurated here, It was built at the private expense of a Haggi Mohamed Muhareb, a wealthy Luxorite, who made his. money a9 dragoman and dealer in antiquities. All the Loxor notables were present at the ceremony, and also the principal European residents. There was a good show of bunting, sundry speeches were made, and as is usual on such occasions, healths were drunk ia lemonade and champagne.

Yesterday we had sever steamers . in oar harbour loading and uploading, viz., four Khedivial Mail steamers, the Fayoum, Mariat, Dakablieh, and Missir, one British Persian Gulf steamer Naderi, one British (Frank, Strick & Co.'s) Gulistan, and the Haggi Daoud Company's Maria. Trade prospects would seem to be bright. There is an enormous amount of merchandise now passing between here and Khartoum by rail. The Sudan Government Railways are running a special goods train daily, besides the regular passenger trains.

The Khedivial Mail Co. have also decided to run two direct mail steamers a week from Suez to Suskin, and Frank, Strick & Co. have informed the Saakin merchants and railway that they will also commence to run their steamers regularly direct from England to Saakin and Port Sadan.

One of the passengers by the Khedivial Mail steamer Dakablieb, which leaves this. Morning is Dr. Ibrahim Effendi Pahmy, for over three years Senior Medical Officer Soakin Government Hospital, who is now transferred to Abbassieh Hospital, Cairo. Spain loses in Dr. Fahmy one of the most kind-hearted of doctors, who was continually doing good both among the poor natives as well as the Europeans.

div.head:
THE ADMIRAL DEWEY.
ARRIVAL AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Saez, Tuesday,
The floating dock Admiral Dewey, reached Saez safely this afternoon at 5.30 in tow of two tugs.
No steamers were allowed to enter the Canal tha whole of to-day, owing to the passage being engaged by the dock.

div.head: THE CONGAL AGAIN.
div.p: Port Said, Monday.

The S.S. Congal, which was sunk in March last year by the S.S. Statesman, and which the Canal Company raised at a cost of £1,400 in Jane, was sold to a syndicate for £3,500 and they in their turn resold her at a profit to a Greek company, after having effected some slight repairs to her. Last Friday morning she went to sea, and last night returned again in tow of the French steamer Ville de Tamatave. The captain of the Ville stated that he sighted the Congal early yesterday morning and arranged to tow her back to Port Said for & certain sam, which I understand the captain of the Congal denies. The Congal is still anchored in the roads, and I have been unable to find out the reason of her return.

div.head: GALLABAT TRADE.
div.p: Trade at Gallabat is reported to be slnok. There was, in March, a large decrease in the imports, amounting to about 57% and in coffee to about 68% and in animals to sboat 48%. A slight increase in exports is reported during March, being 11% in exports in general. This is dae, it is said, to the fact that the Dankur trade route is getting to be more popular with merchants.

div.head: TOKAR COTTON.
div.p: At Tokar we learn that 1,500 kantars of cotton were sold up to the end of Maroh at an average price of P.T. 80 per kantar (small). Cotton grown from Egyptian seed of 1905 is said to be of an exceptionally good quality.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LOAN DRAWING.
div.p: A public drawing of £40,400 nominal capital of the Egyptian Guaranteed Three per Cent. Loan will bake place at the offices of the Caisse de la Datts, in Cairo, on May 12, and the bonds 80 drawn will be payable on September 1, with the coupon then due.

div.head: THE NEW HISTORY OF EGYPT.
div.p: If any one should ask what necessity there was for yet another history of ancient Egypt, added to the score already on our shelves, the answer is that such books need renewal almost as often aq almanac and time-tables.The extraordinary advance of discovery in Egypt, both in excavation of monuments and in publication of texta, 'makes whole chapters obsolete in a very few years. It seems only the other day that De Morgan and Petrie for the first time set the dynasty of Menes on a solid foundation, and disclosed traces of the earliest ages of Egyptian history previously unknown Every year the patient labours of an increasing band of explorers bring fresh evidence to light, and the no less patient studies of scholars at home reduce the vast mass of material, new and old, to order and correlation. We shall never have done with Rotissag the history of Egypt so long as there is an acre of possible monumental sites to be dug up. All that we can demand is the presentation of the latest evidence interpreted by accurate scholarship. This we undoubtedly possess in Professor Breasted's learned work, the latest product of the American school of research, which bids fair to rival the best results of European scholarship. The Chicago professor is not content to rely upon any secondary authority; he distracts copyists, however eminent, and insisted upon going straight to the original documents himself. This involved years of labour in the museums of Earope and Cairo, and among the monuments still remaining in situ in Egypt. No doubt he has his own personal equation of error; but his freali collation of nearly all the existing historical documents has enabled him to eliminate numerous misreadings and to produce a series of texts more accurate as a whole than any published before. These appear in his "Ancient Records of Egypt," a large collection of verified documents, upon which the present history is based, and to which references are given in substantiation of most of his statements. The | book is thus written mainly at first hand, and is authoritative according to the mass of his materials and the measure of his scholarship. Some exceptions might be taken to his general manner of ignoring all previous research by other workers, but this is simply the method of his history. He will allow no interpreter to come between him and the original document, which he invariably examines for himself without bias from others, and only after he has formed his own conclusions does he compare the results of previous interpreters. This is unquestionably the right way to set to work, as Professor Petrie has himself inflexibly laid down ; and never before has the fall documentary evidence of Ezyptian history bɔen brought together so completely or with simpler means of verification.
A History of Egypt from the Earliest Times to the Persian Conquest. By James Henry Breasted, Ph.D., with 200 illustrations and maps. (Hodder and Stoughton, 20s. net).

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.B. Ghazi Mokhtar Pacha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissione; leaves Cairo by special train to-morrow at 9.45 4. m., accompanied by his civil and military household, and will arrive at Hadra station at 1.20 p.m.

Mr.F.G. Freeman, late H M. Vice-Consul at Alexandria, is leaving Alexandria this afternoon by the Khedivial Mall steamer for Constantinople en route to Trebizond to take up his new duties as Consul in that Black Sea port.

Mr. Leon Soares arrived at Alexandria from Cairo yesterday, and leaves at the end of the month for Earope with Mrs. Felix Saarès. On returning from Karope Mrs. Felix Saatda and her family will settle at Kasr-el-Dobara, As it is their intention to leave their beautiful house at Kasr-el-Nil.

On Monday a "punch d'honneur" was offered to the distinguished layers, Mes. Leon Renault and Villa, by the Cairo Janior Bar, Bloquent speeches were delivered by Me Concozzi on behalf of the Junior Bar, and by MM. Renault, Villa, and Carton de Wiart.

Forty of the senior members of the Ba. gave a dinner in honour of Mee. Villa and Renault on Saturday in the garden of Shepheard's. Me Carton de Wiart presided, and proposed the health of his two eminent confrères in a brilliant speech. Me. Villa. and Me. Renault replied, the former warmly thanking the Egyptian Bar for its reception, while the latter in a humorous and witty speech spoke of the Bar as a profession and told somb interesting stories of the baat-known leaders of the Bar of France.
The death is announced of Mr. Theodore L. Soanavi, a well-known member of one of the oldest Greek families in Alexandria.
We regret to hear that the son of Daninos Pacha is suffering from typhoid fever.

The marriage took place on Monday, at St. Catherine's Cathedral, of Mlle Henriette Baolt to Mr. Alfred Zarb, of the Khedivial Mail Line. A reception was subsequently held at the Hotel Abbat, and was largely attended by the namerons friends of the happy pair, who left yesterday by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Hungaria,to spend their honeymoon in Europe.

MAY DAY IN FRANCE.
PARIS IN EXCITED STATE.
700 ARRESTS MADE.
CROWD CHARGED BY POLICE.

Paris, May 1. A lieutenant in uniform harangued tha strikers at a meeting here. He declared that his treatment in the army had made him a convert to Socialism : he will not permit goldiers to shed the blood of their comrade. He has been arrested.
(Reuter)

Paris, May 1. The city is in an excited state. By eleven 150 persons had been arrested for refusing to circulate. The crowd stoned Chatsapdeau barracks : police charged and arrested them. Up to now no disturbances have taken place in the provinces. It is estimated that 20,000 persons have left Paris for fear of distarbanp89. * Many scoffil 3s between the poliée and the demonstrators have taken place : the police were repeatedly compelled to charge, and once, when stoned, they received orders to fire in the air. The Place de la République was cleared by cavalry but the troops and police were discreetly handled and few. were hurt. 700 arrests were made, including the Germis Socialist delegates. The demonstrations in the provinces passed off peacefully, rain aiding the authorities.
(Reuter)

Paris, May 1. Most of the shops are open, but the circulation of carriages is very restricted. There is no animation, except in the neighbourhood of the Bourse de Travail, where numerous meetings are being held..
The police dispersed several gatherings. Several people were slightly injured, and six or seven hundred arrests were made.
Telegrams from the departments do not report any serious incident. Some disturbances took place at Brest, Toulon, Marseilles, and Bordeaux
(Havas)

div.head: EVENING ENTERTAINMENT AT SHEPHEARD'S.
div.p: A most successful evening entertainment took place at Shephsard's Hotel on Wednesday last. Unfortunately it was impossible to start at 9:30 punctually, owing to the large dining hall being packed with visitors. Dinner over, however, the place was quickly converted, the stage erected, hairs placed in position, eto., and the audience soon filled the hall. A splendid programme was then gone through, each performer receiving vociferous cheering. Major Donegan, with his original song, fairly "brought down the house," as also did Lieut. Adams and Mr. Trimen; in fact it is hardly fair to enlogise any particular individual, as every one was such a sighsl 8000088. The. sentimental singing of Mrs. Roussin, MA Hayes, and Mr. Wood left nothing to be desired. The audience was treated to plenty of fun, which they greatly appreciated, and all through the evening the hall resounded with roars of hearty laughter.

The attendance was quite beyond expect:tions. The garrison was well represented, General Bullock, Wation Pachs (A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive) and most of the officers of the Army of Occupation being prosent. Tha convert was promoted in aid of the British Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association, and we trust financially it has been a BUCO888. We understand that this was the first of a series of monthly entertainments, and can assert that if the programmes of the forthcoming concerts are kept up to the standard of this one, they cannot fail to be a 8000038: Great credit is due to the committed for their exertions towards making the entertainment each & spleadid success. Thanks are also dae to Capt. Tucker, who, though not on the committee, gave material help.

div.head: PLAGUE GERMS FROM SUEZ.
div.p: A very curious tale is told about the latest plot against the Tear, which was evidently hatobed in Egypt. It is contained in a book entitled "Six Years at the Rassian Court," which was only published this year. The | writer, Miss Elgar, is an Irish lady in attendance on the children of the Imperial family and the book was written with the consent of the Empresa. Ia & chapter devoted to attacks on the Tsar's life there is the following: "The last attempt on the Emperor was most subtle. A parcel posted at Saez was sent, marked Private'. He received it while seated at tea with the Emprese. On being opened it was found to contain a piece of dirty cloth, apparently out from an old pair of trousers. He exclaimed in wonder at receiving such a curious thing. The Empress seized the tongs and, taking the dirty cloth in them, sent it from the room. It was examined and found to be full of plague germs." It would be interesting to know whether the Egyptian Government was communicated with on the matter. Saez is- & small place, and the person who sent a packet to the Tsar from the Post Office there must have been noticed at the moment. It must have been evidently somebody connected with the medical profession who sent the parcel from Egypt.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain J. R. White, D S.O., 2nd Battalion Gordon Highlanders, has been chosen for service with the Egyptian Army, and joins atCairo at an early date. We need hardly say that Captain White is the son of Field Marshal Sir George 8. White, V.C., the gallant Ulster veteran, who kept the flag flying over hard-pressed. Ladysmith. Captain White entered his father's old regiment, the "Gay Gordons," in January, 1899, and was promoted captain in 1904. He served in the Boath | African War, including the advance on Kim berley, the actions of Magersfontein, Paardeberg, Poplar Grove, Driefontein, Vet River, Zund River, the operations in the Transvaal. including the engagements of Johannesburg and Pretoris ; the operations east and west of Pretoria, the actions of Belfast and Lydenburg and the operations generally in Cape Colony, Orange River Colony, and the Traps vaal, down to the close of the war (mentioned in despatohés, D.3.0, Queen's medal with five olasps, King's medal with two clasps)
Lieutenant Leonard Bouefield, R.A.M.C., presently stationed in Malta, has been selected for service with the Khedive's Army. He "received his commission in the R A.M.C. in January, 1902.
Captain B. B. Hankey, Worcestershire Regiment, who was recently serving with the Egyptian Army, has been appointed on extra aide de camp to Admiral Sir F.G.D. Bedford Governor of Western Australia.

Major Oswald H. Ames, 2nd Life Guards, the tallest officer in the Army, is about to retire from the service, in which he has served close to 22 years. It may be recalled that this gigantic officer led the Jubilee procession of 1897.
Recruiting for the regular army is very dull and comparatively few recruits are being got. This is attributed to the increased briskness in the labour market.

Whilst the cruiser Hogoe, Captain B. G. Sbortland, was returning home from the China Station, she ran up the Persian Gulf as far as Muscat to give the Arabs a sight of a big British croirer. They were favourably impressed by her appearance and ber crew. The visit of the Hogue and the Amphitrite has convinced the most sceptical of the turbulent Arabs that Russia is not the only nation possessing big cruisers, a fiction which was firmly believed in during the visit of the Russian cruiser. Askold to the Gulf.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FENCING TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The following appears in General Orders:

"It is notified for information that Officers of the Army will be permitted to attend and take part (at their own expense) in the International Fencing Tournament to be held in connection with the International Exhibition at Milan, which will be open from 21st April to 15th November 1906.

"The Committee of the Circolo degli Ufficiali di Milano, the Military club of the Town, have courteously decided to invite, the Naval and Military Officers of other countries on the | active or retired lists, who may visit Milan while the Exhibition is open, to frequent the Club provided they are introduced by the Consul of their Country. Officers desiring to avail themselves of the invitation, should first call at the British Consulate with proof of their identity."

div.head: BÉLL'S INDIAN AND COLONIAL LIBRARY.
div.p: One of the best series of publications, modelled on the Tauchnitz system, "for circulation in India and the colonies only," is Messrs. George Bell and Sons' Indian and Colonial Library. Among the latest additions to this collection is & most interesting account of the private life of the Rogsian Imperial family, entitled "Six Yesrs at the R7ssian Court." The writer is an Irish lady, who was an attendant on the children of the Tear. There is so much falsehood written about the Emperor's family life that it is pleasant to come across an obviously truthful account.

Another recent addition to the same library is the "Great Lord Burghley" by Maria Home The period dealt with and the great statesman, who exercised a more power for influence than any other Englishman, afford plenty of scopa for historical reading of a most absorbing kind, and it would be difficult to discover a more interesting historical work published this year.
All Mesars. Bell's publications are well printed and remarkably cheap in price, and the works selected are well-chosen. We do not know of a better "Colonial Library" than this excellent series.

div.head:
THE APOCALYPSE OF AKABA
THE SECRET PACT OF MERASSIM KIOSQUE.
div.p: (FROM AN OCCASIONAĻ CORRESPONDENT).
Constantinople, April 26.

The political horizon has been more or less clouded over ever since the New Year. Whence and why this atmospheric phenomenon is a matter for corjactore. Possibly it is the result of the eruption of the political Vesuvius which Europe has lately witnessed at Algeciras, but which, happily for Morocco, has been beneficial in blowing off a dangerous quantity of political energy that had been accumulating.

But whatever its origin, the lowering sky is far from pleasant, and there is not a tey anxioge, as well as interested, watchers on the lookout for what is looming ahead. The political atmospheric phenomena are rendered all the more trying at present because Egypt is experiencing a new phase in her political life. At home there is & National movement for constitutional rights, an agitation which we most condemo as premature. In her foreign relations, Egypt. is being bustled on all sides. Turkey is intriguing in Sinai ; Tripoli in Barbary is the theatre of the commercial rivalries and political squabbles of the Powers, headed, 80 says "Le Temps," by Germany, while, southwards, in Equatorial Africa, the Congo Free State has been giving as no little trouble over another of those vexations frontier misunderstandings.

The quarter, however, in which Egypt is mostly interested and wrongly so, a8 will be subsequently shown-is in Sinai. Egypt's quarrel with Turkey regarding the title deeds to this peninsula world soon be over here it's merely a question of the definite delimitation of all hitherto vaguely charted desert.But, unhappiest it is not this aspect of an otherwise insignificant frontier dispute which is worrying the British Government. What they are anxious to find out is the motive which led the German Em. peror t) support H.I.M. the Sultan in his invasion of Bgyptian territory.

The student of Oriental politics who has marked the growth of friendship between Germany and Turkey of recent years will be curious to ascertain the reason. That is German Majesty is a disciple of the Ottoman Despot, and has essayed him. port the Sultan's system of centralisation into the Teton Confederation, is & fact patent to all. What is not so clear is, Why should William II. take it upon himself to champion the cause, not only of Turkey, bat of Islamism at large, and second the Sultan's claim to the Spiritual Ralership of one third of the population of the world The reason is not far to seek. It is attributable to the fact] that the Kaiser has been compelled to be that Champion because he has committed himself to the Sultan. It was seven years ago that he committed himself, and since then there have been various peculiarities in his policy to! suggest this position to the keen observer, bat they were pot and efficient. Time has been pe008sary to sound this peculiar policy to the very. bottom. Some fipal proof was needed and at last it has been found in the Akaba intrigue. which has brought to light the truth of what previously was matter of conjecture. This intrigue is dae, first to the Kaiser's Turcophile policy, and in the next place it hugged after the lapse of seven years revealed the true object of the Kaiser's visit to Constantinople in the autumn of 1898.

The object of that visit was officially described as betokening the friendship of the Kaiser and the Soltan. Sach, indeed, it truly was. But the language of diplomacy never betrayed its real meaning. The official announcement was a partial truth to cloke the political character of that automa errand.

What passed over the coffee oops in Merassim Kiosque has now been disclosed by Akabe. In a tone and manner which most have required considerable rehearsal, the Kaiser imparted to his Imperial host the sentiments of apprehension that he felt regarding the threatening attitude of Egypt, backed up by Great Britain, towards Mecca, and of her intentions of usurping the right of the Turkish Caliph as Lord Paramount of the Hedjaz; and ed, in tarn, of the Mohammedan world: Presumably, also, he explained the support of Great Britain to Egypt's designs as being dictated by her interests in India. It was, briefly, to frighten the Sultan that William II. went to Stambool. In unfolding to his Otto man Majesty the scheme which he--and not Izzat Pache-thought would counterAct Egypt's designs, the Kaiser took care to Conceal the ulterior object he bad) in view, 'namely, of opening ap the rich provinces of Asia Minor to German enterprise, The Sultan thought only of his mənaoed prerogative as spiritual head of the Holy Mohammedan Empire ; details such as working the Hedjaz Railway with 'German' engineers and offering the Army in Syria with German instructors were Subordinate to the general scheme and as each passed unnoticed. Properly frightened, Abdul Hamid lent a willing ear to the councils of his German friend and readily approved the plan of the Hedjaz Railway that had long previously been prepared at Potsdam.

The Kaiser had won in so far as Tarkih policy was concerned, and since then Germany has further strengthened her position in Asia Minor, but for these concessions to German industry its champion had to do something for his money, and the twofold task that now devolved upon him was to divert Boropean attention from the strategic Hejaz Railway. until such time as it was sufficiently near Mecca ; and, secondly, to satisfy the Sultan by some move or other, like the present one at Akata, that his suspicions regarding Egypt's moditated aggression on the Hedjaz was justified.

All would have worked out as the Kaiser had schemed, and thanks to his initiative and stratagem, German enterprise would have been S.S. red a firm foothold in Asiatio Turkey, to the detriment of British commerce, had not the political crisis in Turkey itself modified the Imperial plane to Boob an extent that for some time Germany feared to lose ber predominant position; in any case, she was forced I to reveal herself in hor trae colours to the | Powers. The interference of the European Concert in Macedonia, and the Naval demon. stration off Mitylene, was a bora trial to the Soltan, bat it was an even greater one to the Kiser, who to justify himself alike in the eyag of Europe and Turkey, had to adopt that fatiguing policy of "ronning will the hare and hunting with the hounds." He succeeded as far as Turkey was concerned, but only after securing for Germany her splendid isolation in Boropean sentiment. At last an opportunity appeared itself to clear himself in the eyes of Abdul Hamid of any complicity in the action of the Powers in the Near East. The Hedjaz Railway had reached M.&n, and in porgaance of the sphere unfolded at Meraglim Kiosque seven years ago, troops were rented down to. Akaba and then posted in the Sinsitio Peninsula. Thus this Akaba/affair is the last card where the Kaisar has deluded the Sultan into believing that he might lose Mecca. Turkey would withdraw. ber troops tomorrow, upon the first request of Egypt. tian Government, were it not for the bogey that the Kaiser for his country's interests has made of Egyptian pretensions. Such a pretension we, may authoritatively declare to be foreign to the intentions of the Govern. ment, which never has harboured such a design. The Akaba intrigue is a sort of test by which the Kaiser hopes to persuade the Sultan of the reality of his suspicions. ing Egyptian aggression ; and the obstinacy of Turkey in maintaining her unwarranted position in Sinai is due to the frantio efforts of the Kaiser to force the Egyptian Government to take violent measures, and so justify his accusation. We should recommend to Egypt to take no such steps, if such were her intention, which we believe not to be.
A policy of passive resistance would at once disillusionist the Sultan first as to' Egyptian menaces, and secondly as to the Kaiser's tears.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH.
div.p: In consequence of the 'ramours prevalent in
London last week respecting the health of the Saltan, the Avìbassador telegraphed to Constant| tirople and received an official reply declaring
that the reports were false. This denial was subsequently sent to the press' by the Tarkish Embassy.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S SUCCESSOR.
div.p: Rochad Effendi, brother of the Sultan and Heir Apparent, who has been siling for some years, has recently grown ill to such an alarming extent as to cause the Sultan to look after the next in succession. Rechad, who is sixty-two years old, is suffering from acute diabetes. The next to the throne, after his demise would not be either of the Sultan's two other brothers, Saleiman or Kemal Eldin, bat Yaxeuf Izzedin, son of Sultan Abdul Aziz, who died in 1876, as he (Yassat) is older than either of the others, and as, according to the Ottoman law of succession, the oldest male in the whole house of Osmin ascends the throne.

Sultan Abdul Hamid is credited with contemplating the abrogation of this law in favour of his favourite son, Barhan Eddin. It is announced that the Sultan chose the Prince's tator, Isket Pacha, to the European Courts a few months ago, with a view of ascertaining whether these Courts would acquiesce in the Sultan's plan. The problem may be part of a practical test before long.

div.head: SHARE FORGERS IN TURKEY.
div.p: Considerable excitement has been caused on the Constantinople Stock Exchange by the dig: covery that a large number of false Transvaal Consolidated shares are in circulation. The shares have been for a long time a favourite speculative stock, and small investors have risked a few pounds continually in buying a few and selling out with a few francz profit. Several arrests have been made, and it has been found out that an Armenian Derbassian, an outside broker, and an Italian. Ginbeca, were the forgers. Darbussian has confessed that some years ago he lost heavily in South Africans, and was now taking his revenge on the market. Giubeca had a printing establishment. ment, and had lately been to Barope and spent about £2,000 in bodying the most perfected machinery, &c., for producing the sharor, which are good imitations of the ones banned in Paris. About £20,000 sterling worth are on the market, but no one seems to know what has become of the proceeds or how they were cir. culated. The Ottoman Bank has not suffered, as it has a rale not to advance more than 10 per cent. on speculative shares, but other establishments which, in their anxiety to obtain busin e-8, advanced 75 per cent, have got a considerable amount

div.head: INTERESTS IN ARABIA.
div.p: GERMAN SUSPICIONS OF ENGLAND.
A leading article in the "Post" of Berlin, which appears concurrently in the "Kreuz Zsitopg" and the National Zeitung," deals with German and English interests in Asia Minor.

It states that from the manner in which the news is received in England of the course of the fight which has for months been carried on bətween the Tarkish troops in the province of Yemen and the insurgent Arabs onder Mohamed Jahja it is evident that the Eng: lish people secretly rejoice at the Torkish reverses, and hope that the South Arabian tribes. will ultimately secure their independence In the latter cate England would undoubtedly find ways and means of extending her influence from Aden, and by treaties with the South Arabian tribes would ultimately Become a predominant position in their territory, inolading Mecca.

**Such a configuration of political conditions in Southern Arabia would, however, be decidedly inconvenient," the article proceeds, "to German interests in Asia Minor, as the English would then undoubtedly use the inflaenog they had acquired in Arabia to menace our economic position in Asia Minor. The Baghdad Railway is a thorn in the flesh of the English as they consider that it threatens their privileged position in the Persian Gulf and they would probably welcome any opportunity for counteracting the growing German interests in Asia Minor. Germany, therefore, cannot but hope that he Tarkish arms will soon prevail in the Yemen."

The article concludes : "It is time that England recognised that Germany also has a right to devote herself to economic enterprises in countries outside her own frontiers, and that such enterprises do not cover an AntiEnglish policy."

div.head: OPENING FOR TRADE IN EGYPT.
div.p: In his report to the Foreign Office on the trade and commerce of Alexandria in 1905, Mr. Vice-Conceal Freeman says that it is highly satisfactory to note that the shipping for the twelve months exceeded that for 1904 by 610 vessels and 383,290 tons. The principal contributor to the increase was the United King. dom, with 181,440 tons, though it was closely followed by Germany, with 140,935 tons. The imports for 1905 amounted to L.E. 19,066,338, against L.B. 18,125,496 in 1904, while exports amounted to L.E.19,3 26,709, compared with L.E. 19,703,721 in 1904. "The principal recommendation suggested to me," says Mr. Freeman, "with a view to the increase of British, trade is again that manufacturers should study the. market more closely. No amount of writing on the part of an agent will help a firm in this study so much as the regular visits of a tra. veller, and, if possible, an occasional personal visit by the head himself. But the traveller ought not to be handicapped by having to adhere rigidly to fixed patterns or designs, 84 much licence as possible should be given to him in this respect. All quotations should be in the weights and currency of this country and c.if Alexandria, not f.o.b, or free into trucks only. More, I think, might be done by British firms in the way of advertising. Posters should be printed in French and Arabic 88. well as Boglish." Among articles for which there are openings, saddlery, watches, rubber tyros, stoves, and glassware are mentioned.

div.head: SHIPPING TRADE IN THE LEVANT.
div.p: The directors of the German Ləvant Steamship Company in their report just published state that the shipping trade in the Near East has been more unfavourable during 1905 Than in the preceding year on account of the troubles in Russia and the establishment of foar competitive services in the Loyant trade. As to the question of rivalry, it is mentioned that a Belgo-Egyptian firm came on the scene first, the Hamburg firm of Menzell and Co. second, the newly-established Atlas Line of Bremen came third, and the United Steamship Company of Copenhagen fourth. The result of the competition, which has now been terminated by friendly agreement, was that freights in the second half of 1905 fell to 58. per ton from Antwerp to Alexandria and Syria. In these circumstances the financial results of the Ger. man Lavant Line in 1905 were less favourable than in 1904, and the profits of £30,781 have been almost entirely devoted to the depreciation of the fleet. The surplus realised in 1904 was higher, but it was insufficient to allow the payment of a dividend.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR:
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex.
pressed by our correspondents, but we wluti, in a spirit of fair play to all, to operate - within certain necessary limita free discussion
CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN Gazette"

Sir,- I trust you will allow me space in yopi columns to ventilate a very serious grievance. I am not one of those who write to the news. paper on the slightest provocation, but I do believe that the Prayers can do something when appeals to an autocratic body with a monopoly --Buch as the Cairo Water Company--fail hopelessly.

I have been a resident in Cairo for several years, and it has been my misfortune to have a flat-on the second floor of a building in the Ismailia quarter. Bach sommer I hiva potjoed the same phenomenon, viz., that directly the Savoy Hótel closed, poop in the vicinity of it, on the second floor, got no water during the day, although as long as the hotel was open, they had a plentiful supply. I have tried hard to find a clue to the mystery, but so far have tailed. There cannot be a serious fall of the Nile within a few days of the Savoy closing as would account for this lack of water. On the other hand, it would be generous to suppose that the Hotel Company influenced such an upright company as that which pretends to sopplý Cairo with water. A company which pays such large dividends (at the expense of the public), and which gives auch entire satis. faotion (during the tourist season) is surely above such suspicion.

I have found that appeals to my landlord aid to the Water Company both fail, and I therefore appeal to you, Sir, to help the poor waterless ones in these days of khamseen. If ye do not do so at once, it will be too late, as the director of the Water Works will be on his way home (where water is plentiful), and Lord Cromer-ea well. We must strike the iron while it is hot.

Joking apart, it is a crying scandal and disgrace to Cairo that nothing is done to keep this precious Water Company in hand. I have carefully studied the so-called agreements between the Government and the Water Company, and endeavoured to find a single clause under which it was possible to bring these people to book, with no result.

Very agreement-it is only too clear-has been drawn up in the office of the Water Company, and the last agreement of all, to judge. by its puerile simplicity-from the Govern: ment point of view - by the office boy of that company. As the Government, therefore, sro tied hand and foot in the matter, nothing remains to the public bat to keep on agitating against such a company. It is not a matter for surprise, in the circumstances, that there is so much typhoid fever in Cairo ; bat-it really is amazing that in such a pseudo' up to date city this intolerable state of things should be allowed to exist.

For obvious reasons, I do not think it necessary to sign this letter with my proper name, bat should the Water Company attempt any kind of defence of their misdeeds, I shall be only too happy to disclose my identity and give chapter and verse for the accusation I have brought against this shockingly inefficient corporation.—I am, etc

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle).
La Délégation Municipale s'est réanie le 1er Mai 1906 & 4h. p m., sous la présidence de M. le Dr. Scbiess Pacbe.
Présents : MM. Ahmed Pacha Yehia, Man. soor Bey Youssef, Baron A. de Menasce, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensid, membrer, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
La Délégation définit les dispositions qui de vront faire l'objet de l'arrêté interdisant le colportage des viandes.

Le colportage des viandes et abats gera rigoureusement défendu. Cette interdiction comprendra également le colportage da pois. Bon; toutefois, pour cette dernière denrée, des emplacements seront fixés où la vente pourra en être autorisée. A cette occasion, la Délégation compte qo'ane prompte solation sera dongée bla question de la création de marchés pablics.
Sar la demande de M. Matragi, et de l'avis conforme da vétérinaire en chef, la Délégation loi accorde l'indemnité établie par le Comité spécial pour des chevaux morvoox qai lai ont été abattae.
La Délégation - renvoie au rapport des fervices les offres présentées par divers foardia. Beurs pour la fourniture de tayaux en grès.

Blle soumettra à la Commission Municipale one lettre du 25 avril du Ministère de l'Inté. rieor infornant que de l'avis conforme du Ministère des Finances, le Conseil des Ministres a approavé la cession au Chiakhat des Uléma d'Alexandrie, des terrains de l'Etat sis au War' lian.

La Délégation communiquera également à la Commission Manicipale une lettre da 26 avril 1906 de 8.E. le Ministre de l'In érieur informant que le Ministère des Finances serait disposé à contribuer à la dépense à encourir pour la constraction de trois ponts gar le Mah. moudieh pour one sabvention de L. E, 6,000 qui équivaut à peu près au tiers de l'évalua. tion de la construction de ces ponts.

La Délégation prend connaissance d'une lettre da 26 avril de l'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat transm sttant un plan d'ensemble des modifications qu'elle se pro pose d'apporter à la garé des voyageurs d'A lexandrie.

Un échange de vaes a lieu à cet égard, a la guite daquel, la Délégation charge l'Administrateur de se mettre en rapport avec M. Johnston, Diraoteur Général de l'Administra. tion des Chemins de fer de l'Etat.

A cette occasion, M. de Menasce émet l'idée, étant donné que la voie ferrée constituą one séparation entre deux qaartiore importanta de la ville at condamne en quelque sorte celai de Moharrom Bey à être isolé et difficilement accessible au reste de la Ville, qa'il conviendrait de profiter des modification à l'étade poor proposer de mettre la voie ferrée jusqu'à la sortie de ls ville dans an tannel, soit ouvert, soit fermé, de te!le sorte qu'elle ne puisse constituer an obstacle aux communications.

La Dé égation renvoie au Conseil da Tanzime, aveo avis favorable, an projet relatif à l'élar gissement de la rue Gabel Zaitona et an Comité des Travaux Pablios divera projeto concernant la route de la Corniche, la constraotion d'ane route de 30 mètres depuis la tranchée de l'Ibrahimieh jasqı'à Balkeley ainsi que celle d'ane routa de 20 mètres paral. lèle à celle de 30 mètres.
La séance est levée à 7 b. p.m.

Ainsi que nous l'avons fait prévoir dans nos précédents bulletins, le marché s'alourdit de plus en plus à cause des règlements de fin de mois.
Les affaires, d'ailleurs très clajrsemées, se limitent aux Agrioole, Crédit Foncier, Delta Land, Nile Land, Comptoir et Union Foncière.

Les Banques sont également faibles et de laissées. Le Banco di Roma, entre autres, tombe à 113 1/2.
Seule en hausse la Nile Land s'avance de 15 3/4 à 16 1/2 pour olótarer à 16 3/8.

div.head: SEMOULERIE PERFECTIONNEE
div.p: "LELYS"

J'ai l'honneur d'informer le public et ptas, spécialement ma respectable clientèle que, tout en gardant mon moulin à farines de Ta 8008 (Torqoie d'Asie). fondé en 1890. je viens d'installer à Alexandrie une betodlerie de tout dernier modèle fonc'ionnant d'après les sys tèmes perfectionnés les plus récents de France et de Suisse. Grâce à ma longue expérience dans ca genre d'industrie, ainsi qu'aux moyens exceptionnels dont je dispose pour m'approvisionner en blés de tout premier choix an Syrie, dans le Levant et en Russie, j'espère douvoir donner pleine et entière satisfaction sous tous les rapports.
Dans l'espoir que voas voudrez bien me con: server votre pratique et faire l'essai da produit de ma nouvelle asine,
Agréez, eto.
GABRIEL MARINO. Mon huren ne trouve à côté de la Poste de Ras-el-Tin-Téléphone N° 17-68-et l. fabri. que dans le même quartier, Rue Gonda:
P.S. - Os pont se procurer daus le même établissement du bon, des criblures et de la farine.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, mardi ler mai.

Le taux de l'escompte à Londres, qui avait été rédait de 1/4 en deux jours, vient d'être de nogvean élevé de 1/8 à 3 3/8. Ces oscillations semblent indiquer que le marché moné. taire n'a pas tout-à-fait repris son caractère normal par suite des retraits d'or pour l'Amérique.

Hier, at Stock Exobange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 90 3/8 et l'Unifiés à 106. 1/4. La National Bank & réactionné de 1/8 à 26 1/2 et l'Agricole d'antant à 10 1 4. La Daïra est demeurée inchangéa á 17 5/8. La Delta Light a regagné H8 à 12 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Bzyptien s'est maintenae å 780 et la Banque d'Athènes * 150.
Ce matin encore, notre marché des valeurs a été calme et sans affaires, aveo tendance légère à la réaction sur toute la ligne de la I cote, à deux ou trois exceptions près.

La National Bank, délaissée, a cloturé à 26 7/16. Egalement peu animée, l'Agricole est restée entre 10 1/32 et 10 1/16. Le Comptoir Financier est revena 7 1/2, la Banque d'Athènes à 151,"la Banque d'Orient à 140.
L'action Crédit Foncier est demeurée immo bile à 782 ; l'obligation lots 1836 a été traitée à 323 ex-coapon ; la nouvelle à 270.
Bon mouvement sur les Improvements, qui ont avancé à 5 13/32 pour oltarer à 5 1/45/16. Les Nile Land ont été également l'objet de nombrsuses transactions et ont progressé à 15 7/8.

L'action Wardan Estate & fait 6.3/4'; la part de fondatear 8 7/8. FL'Union Foncière a été traitée à 6 5/8-2 11/16. Suivant des informations d'Alexandrie, le mouvement de haussa qui s'est desainé ces jours derniers sur ce titre est attribué l'ap. proche de la fin da premier exercice, dont les résultats seraient excep.fopnellement satisfaisants. Les acquisitions de terrains faites par la Société se montéraient à L.B. 400,000. Or, on calculerait que si ces terrains étaient revendus anjurd'hai, ils laisseraient un bénéfice net d'environ L.B. 160,000 $07 op capital social de LB. 500,000, ce qui représenterait du 32 %.
Les Onnibus da Caire ont fléchi à 28 1/2-3/4..
Rien de saillant à relever sur les autres valears.
Le groupe des Hotels a été inactif. Les Nangovich étaient offerts à 17 1/2.

Dabs le compartiment des petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été complètement négligés. Les Estates ont été ramenés à 1 13/16 et la part de fondateur à 11 1/2-3/4. Los New Bzyptian ont cločaré /30 sh. 3 et les Walker and Maimarachi à £0 3/4-13/16. Les salt and Soda ont filohi à 22 sh. 3. Les Markets ont pragressé à 27 sh. 3, après avoir atteint 28.
L'émission de la Société des Excelsior Hote's a été couverte à pan près deux fois.
Les souscriptions de 1 à 500 actions seront allonées intégralement. Les bouscriptions supérieures à ce dernier chiffre subiront une réduotion proportionnelle.

Rappelons que l'émission de la Cairo saburban Bailding Lands Co., dont nous avons parlé dans notre Circalaire d'hier, a lieu demain. Lsouscription sera ouverte dans la matinée à l'Anglo-Bgyptian Bank, an. Caire et à Alexandrie, . et c'tarée à 5 hearas de l'après-midi.
Nous restons à la disposition de ceux de dos clients qui von iraient so ascrire par notre entremise.

Les parts de divider da de la Société des Tramways électriq783 da Caire poursuivent lear mouvement ascensionnel sur le mardhé de Bruxelles. Les ooars apportés par le dernier courrier (23 avri) étaient de 925-930 france.
Les coora da coton sont arrivéi en hausse d'Amérique. Hier, le disponible a gagné 5 points, le Mai et l'Octobre 9 points respectivement.
Lou arrivagas à New-York ont été de 16,000 balles contre 17,000
Le marché de Liverpool est topjours stationnaire. .
Ici, le Mai, foi a fiai hier soir faible á 20 13/33 sar de fortes réalisations, malgré les achats da commerce, a ouvert ce matin à 20 11/16/poor clotarer å 20 21/32.

On nous câble de New Orleans que les exportatears font de grands achate. Des pluies sont absolument nécessaires poor assurer la récolte. D'autre part, des avis de New-York portent que le marché semblerait être à découvert.

div.head: THE TABAH AFFAIR.
div.p: COMMENTS OF HOME PRESS.
regarding orollary of was to be me

The home Press seems to have instantly accepted the announcement that the British -garrison in Egypt was to be reinforced as a natural corollary of the obduracy of Turkey regarding the Tabah incident. Commenting on this the "Tribune" says :

"It is a sign that we accept the responsibility of protecting Egypt from aggression and the action of Turkey has left us with no immediate alternative. Not only has she seized territory which Egypt regards as hers, and persisted in holding it in spite of protests, but she has taken an equally high ling in her negotiations. She affects to regard the dispute as a purely domestic concern between Turkey and a vassal State in which no other Power has any concern. However difficult and undefined our own position is in Egypt, we could hardly submit to being ignored in such a question ; we are bound to insist on our rights as the protecting Power in military occupation in Egypt. At the same time, while we could hardly refuse to take up a challenge so directly, this practice of enforcing points in a diplomatic argument: by a display of armed force is in general objectionable, and needs to be watched very carefully to let it run away with us. It logically implies that in the last resort we are prepared for war ; and while & direct refusal on the part of Turkey to recognise that we have any position in Egypt ogold hardly have any other result, we should make it quite clear that we should not dream of using force to settle a simple question of fact - whether the Sinai Peninsula is Tarkish or Egyptian territory. This distinction between the larger political question and the smaller questions of fact should be kept constantly to the front. We must assert, our right: 18 the Power in military occupation of Egypt; bat! if Turkey withdrew from the occupation of the disputed points we should doubtless be quite willing to refer questions of fact to an arbitral court supposing there were no other way of obtaining & settlement. We might even supplement that policy by taking steps to get our position in Egypt regularised, and to obtain a formal international mandate! in place of the informal one that the absence of objection and the lapse of time may be held to have given de."

The Daily News," writing on the subject, remarks that. " this rather preposterous straggle" about the line of demarcation in the Sinai peninsula has been characterised by the astal tricks of Saltanio diplomacy. We are ever on the point of being satisfied, and never are satisfied. The Saltan negotiates and sends delegates who disappear apparently into space. He yields and returns to his position as though nothing bad happened. That has ever been the way of the Sultan, who has never understood & menace or a threat which did not take the shape of a battleship. The claim of the Sultan to Tabah and the ports along the Boothern section of the Peninsula is baged 6 upon a telegram sent by the Grand Vizier on the occasion of the scoassion of the present Kbp Dive in 1892, declaring that Tabsh was an integral part of the Empire, belonging to the district of Akatab. It seems an odd thing to base a claim to a portion of the earth on a telegram. It smacks more of the Kaiser than of the Sultan. Sironger grounds would certainly! have to be showo, for the word of the Sultan, like that of a certain English king is one that "no man relies on." It was reported at the end, of last month that the redaction of the Tark'sh. force at Aqabah indicated that the Sultan was giving way. But the fact remains that the Torks are still at Tabah, and we venture to ' think they will be there as long as diplomacy is civil and not military.'

div.head: "THE ARAB REVOLT."
div.p: In view of the present crisis arising out of the Akaba affair, a book on Arabian politics will be welcome to all interested in them, especially as regards the complicated and vaguely-determinate relations between Turkey and Egypt. Sach a work has come to us from the pen of M. Bugen. Jang, formerly French Vice-President in Indo-China, who has dedicated this book, "Les Puissances devant la Révolte Arabe" (Hachette et Cie., 79. Boulevard Saint, in Germain, Parir) to Negib-Azoury Boy, late Aljatant Governor of Jerusalem, whom he describes as "the ardent patriot, the instigator of the Arab National Movement, the fervent 'friend of France." Dealing exhaustively, though in no wearisome manner, with every aspect of the Arab problem-political, economica, international-his remarks are a revelation not only of the Arab question, but of the more complicated one of the Near East. A true sont of France, a reference to German politics is E pardonable, but for all his opposition, M, Jung never descends from the level of even-tempered, impartial criticism, a characteristic which will twin for his book a well deserved popularity.
