div.head: CAIRO TEN YEARS AFTER
div.p: The following is part of an interesting article signed William Maxwell," which ap | Peared recently in the "Daily Mail":-

Cairo is no longer a feeble, imitation of Parir. It is tbe gay and débonnaire city herself, with la touch of the East and & snspicion of Wall street. Ten years have wrought an amazing transformation.. Stray beyond the Rsbekiyeb Gardens and yoda are in a new country. The street of a dilapidated stable, where I bought horses for Omdorman is a boulevard of shops and banks and palatial hotels, in which wealthy British, Americans, and Germane seek refuge from winter. The old messman of the t| Highland Regiment is now a bey and a financial magnate, and the modest hostelry where General Wauchope and General Lyttelton drank success to our arms before the advance into the debert has been swept into the background. Then-and Now.

How well I remember that night of nights the hot, moist air, the tables spread on the balloony, the strong, esger fa08a-mapy, alas ! now ghostly memories of the Sudan and South Africa--the cheers that rang out like a battle ory, the toasts that were drunk and the glasses that were cast over the shoulder when the last golden drop was drained. The shattering and shivering of them still sounds in my ears like the olash of steel.

A blew race, as well as a new city has appeared. Those wore the days when many in Cairo preferred the Khalifa to Lord Cromer, and prayed that the blood of our Army would again crime on the sand of the desert. They do not love us even now-these Egyptians. It is not in the nature of a Moslem to show gratitude to a Christian governor. Yet in 1 their hearts they are thankful for the liberty we have given them, for the freedom from oppression, for the new wealth of the land and for the chance of living their own lives. You feel it in the changed manner of the people.

div.head: CAIRO REVISITED.
div.p: Mr. C. H. Napping in the "Jewish Mission ary Intelligence" has an article entitled 'Cairo revisited after many years," from which we extract the following passage :

"In 1869, there was no regular English Church service. A room at the Grand Hotel, which has since disappeared, was fi:ted up for that purpose when a clergyman was available, and I had the privilege of ministering there to a small congregation on the Sunday of my former visit. My dragoman asked me the next day why the English worshipped God at the big grog obop! Now there is a beautiful Baglish church, foll of interesting memorials of Gordon and others who have won fame and died in Egypt, with regular services, surplus

choir, weekly Communion, and the ministry of Dean Batcher. I was glad to find the evening service here better attended, and specially by young men, in comparison with the morning, than is now really the case in well-to-do parishes, at home."

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: The following is the order in which visitors will be received at the Khedivial reception to be held at Ras el-Tin Palace tomorrow :
At 9 a m.-T.H the Princes of the Khedivial Family ; the Ulema; the heads of State Administrations.
At 9.30 am.--The Mixed Magistracy; the Native Magistracy ; Daval and army officers of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards ; civil officials

At 10 a.m.- Unofficial military and civil personages having the rank of Lowa or Oula "Sint Sani and upwards ; naval and army officers onattached and on the retired list having the rank of Kaimakam or Miralai ; unofficial civil Beys having the rank of Banieh and opwarde ; the Municipal Commission.
At 10:30 am. - The Diplomatic and Conso. lar Corps.
At 10.45 am.-Field officers of the Army of Occupation; the clergy.
At 11 am. - Native notables ; European notables.
This reception is reserved to persons resid. ing in Alexandria.
The military will attend in Andreas uniform and civilians in frock coats (redingote).

The civil officials admitted to this reception are those having at least the rank of subdirector or an equivalent rank, and those having at least the grade of Sanieh or of Kaimakam (military), and the magistrates appointed by decree.
The Khedivah will also hold a reception at the Palace to-morrow, The Princesses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies will be received from 10 to 11.30 a.m., and European ladies from 4 to 5 p.m..

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The King has been pleased to give and grant unto Edward Lambton, Beq., Director of Works in the Bgyptian Mini try of Public Works, and Reginald dower Kirton, Esq., M.D., Principal Medical Officer of the Egyptian Prisons Administration, his Majesty's Royal licence and authority that they may respectively accept and wear the Insignia of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, which decoration has been conferred upon them by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by them.

div.head: SENOUSSI MOVEMENT.
div.p: EFFORTS AFTER A MOSLEM EMPIRE
MYSTERIOUS PROPAGANDA IN THE CENTRAL SUDAN.

Advices just to hand from Northern Nigeria indicate renewed activity on the part of the Sepoussists on the eastern frontier ol Borna, the most remote province of the Protectorate bordering on Lake Tchad, and that there has been trouble between them and the French and Germans in that region. The Resident has reported the affair to Bir Frederick Logard at headquarters, adding that some of Rabeh's horsemen have lately visited Bauchi.

With regard to the above, it may be stated that the mysterious influence of the Senoussi and the spread of Benonssist propaganda in the Central Sudan is a matter which always commands the anxious attention of the Protettorato authorities, but so far, owing to the secrecy observed by Senoussist emissaries, no direct evidence regarding the movement is obtainable. 1 The native mallams always deny any knowledge of the matter when questioned. It is, however, a well-known fact that the Mahom the medaus of the Central Sadan hold the belief that the next great Golem empire will have its capital at the holy hill of Bima, which is in the newly opened province of Bauchi, to the north of the river Bende.-Reuter.
The Sultan's Encouragement.

The best of the Senoussi first came into existence in 1843, bat dates its real rise to power from the open encouragement it received from the Saltan, Abdor Hamid, in 1882, who caused one thousand prayer books to be specially printed for the sect, inscribed with the words, "Asking their help in prayer."

Mohammed-es-Senoussi, who died on August 15, 1902, at the age of fifty-eight, lived the life of a veiled prophet in the Kufra oasis in the south of Algeria, but had missionaries in every Mediterranean port with secret signs and words. He was said to be directly descended from the prophet's favourite wife, and had one arm longer than the other, blue eyes, and the infallible mark between the shoulders. By pine millions of Mahomedans in northern Africa he was regarded as the trae Mahdi, and they only waited for his signal to raise the banner of a holy war against the Christiang.
Proof of the Shelkh's Reputation.

His successor, the Sheikh-el-Senoussi, has inherited his influence, a remarkable instance of which came out a few weeks ago. German diplomacy at Constantinople induced the Sultan of Turkey to send a letter to the Sultan of Morcoso suggesting that G-rmany was the true friend of the Moslem world. The ruler of Morocco did not deign to reply to Abdul Hamid, whom he regards as a very inferior personage, but wrote instead to the Sheikh elSenoussi on the subject.

div.head: FRENCH EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: After the Anglo- French Convention con. cerning Egypt certain critics of M. Delcaseé propheried that an immediate consequence of the sacrifice of the position of France in that country would be a falling off of French trade. The latest report of the French Consul at Cairo (the "Times" Paris correspondent observer,) shows that these fea's were groundless.

The entente cordiale has removed all friction between the two countries. The former tension having come to an end, the commercial interests of France immediately profited thereby. As the "Mašin'' points on in its summary of this Consular report on the commercial movement of Egypt, during 1905, for the first time in many years, French trade in Egypt marks an increase, whereas that of Germany has diminished. The increase in French imports is dae to the larger demands for the produce of the Marseilles flour mills. Six million, two hundred thousand franda (£248 009) more of these goods were imported in 1905 than in 1904. French automobiles and, notably in Cairo, electric cars are being imported in constantly increasing numbers. It is a curious fact also that the majority of the provisions for the big Cairo hotels come from Paris or Lyons. Unfortunately these products fizare in the statistics, as German, since the exporters have to employ the German lines, the Compagnie des Messageries not being provided with cold storage.

div.head: LA SUISSE AU LIBAN.
div.p: GRAND HOTEL CASINO AIN SOFAR
MONT LIBAN.

Cet hôtel de tout premier ordre, qui est deyena la propriété de "The National Hotels and Residences Cy.," est situé à 1850 mètres d'altitude. Cette société l'a aménagé de manière à satisfaire à toutes les exigences da confort moderne. Si le "The National Hotels and Residences Cy." a pris la direction de cet établissement, o'est pour en faire un établissement de premier ordre. La compétence de ootte direo-- tion assure à Aïn Sofar une organisation parfaite. L'excellente ouisine đa National Hotel qui a été l'une des causes de sa vogue au Caire, dès sa première année d'ouverture, contribuers également au bon renom d'Ain Sofar.
Le climat est incomparable ; jamais de pluie ni d'orages ; la température, très douce, ne dépasse pas 17 à 20 degrés centigrades au dessus du zéro.

La direction de l'hôtel d'Aïn Sofar a engagé un orchestre italien de tout premier ordre ; elle s'est également assuré le concours de M. Sovezi, le maitre de danse bien connu au Caire, pour organiser des concerts, bals, fêtes de toute sorte ; il est donc certain qu'on ne s'ennuiera pas cette année à Aro Bofar, sans compter le terrain de tennis, le tir aux pigeons, les courses de chevaux et les excursions dans le Liban, l'Antiliban, Balbeok et Damas qui seront organisées au cours de la saison,

Par gaite d'arrangements spéoiaux aveo la maison Th. Cook and Son, des billets d'aller et retour séront délivrés par cette maison comprenant aussi le transport des bagages et le séjour à l'hôtel. Le voyage du Caire à Aïo Sofar peut s'effectuer en 26 begres, bateau et chemin de fer compris. Le prix complet da séjour à l'hotel varie de 9 à 12 fr. par jour et par personne, suivant l'emplacement de la chambre choisie et la durée de ce séjour.
Il s'agit dono, comme on le voit, d'ane villégiatare qui, tout en procurant tout le confort et l'agrément possibles, est encore très économique.

L'eau glacéa des sources d'Aïa 85far a été reconnue effi sace dans le traitoment de la gra. velle ; l'analyse a démontré qu'au point de vue opratif elle n'était pas inférieure à celle d'Evian les Bains.
